statement.tex: \text{Find the points on the curve }x^2+y^2-2x -3 = 0\\ \text{at which the tangents are parallel to the x-axis.}

step.context: \text{Which of the following would be true}\\ \text{for the required tangents?}
step.reason: \text{A line parallel to the x-axis is horizontal.}\\ \text{And horizontal lines have slope = }0.

step.tex: \qquad \begin{align} x^2+y^2-2x-3&=0\\ \implies y&=\sqrt{-x^2+2x+3} \end{align}\\ \begin{align} \therefore y' &= \dfrac{1}{2\cdot\sqrt{-x^2+2x+3}}\cdot \dfrac{d}{dx}(-x^2+2x) \\ &= \dfrac{-2x + 2}{2\cdot\sqrt{-x^2+2x+3}} \\ \text{Hence, }y' = 0 &\implies -2x + 2 = 0 \text{ or }x = 1 \\ \therefore y &= \sqrt{-x^2 +2x+3} = \sqrt{4} = \pm 2. \end{align}\\ \text{Hence, the required points are }(1,2)\text{ and }(1,-2).
step.reason: \text{Chain Rule is your friend here. If }y = \sqrt{g(x)}\\ \text{ then }y'=\frac{dy}{dg}\cdot\frac{dg}{dx} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{g(x)}}\cdot\frac{d}{dx}g(x).
